chunks.topic: CBOE VIX Index - Key Characteristics for Trading
chunks.content: VIX INDEX DEFINITION: Cboe Volatility Index measures market's expectation of future volatility - calculates constant 30-day expected volatility of US stock market. Created by Cboe Global Markets, revolutionized investing as first volatility benchmark. THREE CRITICAL CHARACTERISTICS: (1) INVERSE RELATIONSHIP - VIX tends to move opposite to S&P 500. Expected volatility increases when markets turbulent, falls when prices rising. (2) MEAN REVERSION - Unlike equity indices that can rise indefinitely, VIX generally returns to historical average over time. Volatility cannot move higher in perpetuity and cannot move to zero. (3) HIGH VOLATILITY - VIX significantly more volatile than S&P 500. Since 1990 inception, VIX standard deviation ~6.9%, which is 5x HIGHER than S&P 500 over same period. TRADING IMPLICATION: Mean reversion property makes VIX attractive for volatility trading strategies - spikes don't last forever, calm periods don't either.

VIX FUTURES (Introduced 2004 on CFE): Provide ability to trade volatility futures based on VIX Index methodology. Market participants can hedge portfolio volatility risk DISTINCT from market price risk. Trade based on view of future direction or movement of volatility. MINI VIX FUTURES: At 1/10th size of standard VIX futures contract, allows trading/hedging equity market volatility with more manageable contract size. VIX OPTIONS: European-style options (exercise ONLY at expiration), cash-settled. Trading volatility EXPECTATIONS, not shares or indices. CRITICAL DIFFERENCES: (1) Expiration on WEDNESDAYS, not Fridays like equity options. (2) Prices derived from VIX FUTURES, not spot VIX. (3) Cash settlement only. 2024 MARKET DATA: Options volumes exceeded 11 billion contracts, 126% increase since 2019. Cboe proprietary products hit record 4.2M avg daily volume in Q3 2024, up 13% YoY. EDUCATIONAL RESOURCES: Cboe Options Institute offers VIX Interactive Calculator for learning how VIX and S&P 500 levels change based on inputs.

chunks.topic: VIX Term Structure and Contango (2024 Example)
chunks.content: VIX TERM STRUCTURE: Futures contracts for different expiration months trading at different prices. CONTANGO (Normal State): Later-month contracts trading HIGHER than near-month. Example from December 2024: VIX spot at 14.34, January 2025 futures ~16.42, April/May futures above 18. INTERPRETATION: Traders expected volatility to pick up in early 2025 despite low current VIX. Market pricing in higher future uncertainty. BACKWARDATION (Stressed State): Near-month contracts trading HIGHER than later-month. Occurs during market stress when immediate volatility elevated but expected to decline. TRADING IMPLICATIONS: (1) Contango erodes long VIX positions over time (futures roll down to spot). (2) Backwardation benefits long positions but signals market stress. (3) Term structure shape reveals market expectations about future volatility path. (4) Steep contango = expensive to hold long VIX exposure long-term. STRUCTURE CHANGES: Monitor slope changes - flattening contango or inverting to backwardation signals rising near-term risk.

chunks.topic: IV Percentile Trading Zones and Strategy Selection
chunks.content: IV PERCENTILE vs IV RANK: IV Percentile = percentage of time IV was LOWER than current level over past year (frequency distribution). IV Rank = where current IV sits within 52-week range (range-based). Example: IV Rank 80% and IV Percentile 80% both indicate current IV higher than 80% of past year, but calculated differently. THREE TRADING ZONES: (1) HIGH IV (>70%) - Options EXPENSIVE relative to past year. SELL premium strategies: credit spreads, iron condors, naked puts, short strangles. Benefit from IV contraction and premium decay. (2) MID IV (30-70%) - NEUTRAL zone, requires additional analysis. Not clearly expensive or cheap. (3) LOW IV (<30%) - Options CHEAP. BUYING strategies: long calls/puts, debit spreads, calendars. MEAN REVERSION CONCEPT: Take advantage by selling when IV far above historical norms, collecting higher premiums with expectation volatility returns to average levels, lowering option value. CRITICAL THRESHOLD: Most traders use 70+ for premium selling, but consider upcoming events, market conditions, stock's volatility history.

chunks.topic: Premium Selling Strategies in High IV Environments
chunks.content: HIGH IV DEFINITION: IV Rank/Percentile >70% indicates options premiums relatively high, opportunities for short option strategies. RECOMMENDED STRATEGIES: Short vertical spreads, covered calls, cash-secured puts, short strangles, iron condors. All benefit from IV CONTRACTION (volatility returning to normal) and theta DECAY (time value erosion). PRACTICAL EXAMPLE: Stock with IV Rank 85 and IV Percentile 80. Selling covered calls here = collecting unusually high premium likely to decrease as volatility normalizes. PROFIT MECHANICS: High IV → Sell options → Collect fat premium → IV drops (mean reversion) → Option value decreases → Buy back cheaper or let expire worthless = Profit. RISK CONSIDERATION: Profits depend on REALIZED volatility (actual price movement) vs IV. Even high IV trades may lose if realized volatility EXCEEDS expectations. Don't assume high IV automatically means profitable trades. EARNINGS WARNING: Watch upcoming earnings dates - stocks can make big moves following announcements regardless of IV levels. Separate earnings plays from general high IV plays.

TIMEFRAME: Stay between 30-60 DTE for vertical spreads. Preference for MONTHLY expiration cycles (most liquid). Avoid weeklies unless specific reason. DIRECTION FIRST: Determine directional bias BEFORE selecting strikes. Bullish = short put vertical OR long call vertical. Bearish = short call vertical OR long put vertical. STRIKE WIDTH: Risk increases with widening of strike price legs. $1-wide spread = less risk than $10-wide spread. Trade-off: narrower spreads = less capital at risk but also less profit potential. Wider spreads = more capital at risk but higher profit potential. SHORT PUT VERTICAL (Bullish Credit Spread): Sell higher-strike put (expensive), buy lower-strike put (cheaper) = net CREDIT. Same expiration. Short put closer to money. SHORT CALL VERTICAL (Bearish Credit Spread): Sell lower-strike call (expensive), buy higher-strike call (cheaper) = net CREDIT. Same expiration. Short call closer to money. LONG CALL VERTICAL (Bullish Debit Spread): Buy lower-strike call (expensive), sell higher-strike call (cheaper) = net DEBIT. Long call closer to money. LONG PUT VERTICAL (Bearish Debit Spread): Buy higher-strike put (expensive), sell lower-strike put (cheaper) = net DEBIT. Long put closer to money.

chunks.topic: Tastytrade Vertical Spread Exit and Management Rules
chunks.content: PROFIT TARGET RULES: CREDIT SPREADS (Short Verticals) - Close at 50% of max profit. Example: $200 credit received → exit when can buy back for $100 = $100 profit locked. DEBIT SPREADS (Long Verticals) - Close at 50% of max profit. NAKED OPTIONS COMPARISON: Tastylive research shows close naked options at 60-65% profit, but spreads at 50%. Why earlier on spreads? Capital efficiency and tail risk protection make 50% optimal for spreads. EARLY ASSIGNMENT RISK: Short shares assignment risk exists especially near expiration. MUST have plan to close or roll position before expiration to avoid assignment, particularly if account lacks equity for resulting position. ASSIGNMENT MANAGEMENT: If assigned early on defined-risk spread, use COVERED STOCK ORDER to close long option and assigned shares simultaneously. Whether assigned short stock (from short call) or long stock (from short put), covered stock order maintains defined risk. NEVER LEG OUT: Separating assigned stock and long option into separate closing orders may INCREASE overall max loss from assignment. Platform will show warning if attempting to leg out. ANYTIME EXIT: Can exit options position whenever market open - don't have to wait until expiration. Create OPPOSITE trade of one initiated in single transaction.

chunks.topic: Vertical Spread Risk Management and Position Sizing
chunks.content: DEFINED RISK NATURE: Vertical spreads are defined-risk positions. Max loss = width of strikes - premium received (for credits) OR max loss = premium paid (for debits). Cannot lose more than initial risk defined at entry. MARGIN REQUIREMENTS (Credit Spreads): Margin = (strike width × 100) - premium received. Example: $5-wide put spread, $200 credit = ($500 - $200) = $300 margin held. This is MAX loss. SHORT SHARES ASSIGNMENT: Critical risk near expiration if short strike ITM. If assigned short stock from short call OR long stock from short put, account must have sufficient equity. Plan ahead - close or roll before expiration week if threatened. LIQUIDITY CONSIDERATIONS: Monthly expirations most liquid. Tight bid-ask spreads critical for entering and exiting efficiently. Avoid illiquid underlyings where spread width eats into profits. POSITION SIZING: Since max loss defined, can size positions based on portfolio % risk. Common approach: risk 1-2% of portfolio per spread. Example: $50k portfolio, willing to risk $1k = can enter spread with $1k max loss. DIVERSIFICATION: Don't concentrate all capital in single direction or underlying. Spread risk across multiple positions, expirations, underlyings. PROFIT VS RISK RATIO: Credit spreads typically offer 20-40% ROC (return on capital at risk). Example: $300 max risk, $100 credit = 33% ROC if expires worthless. Evaluate if probability of success justifies this return.
